Academic_Excellence.text_content:
Subscribe Now! Get features like
For Niranjan Kumar, 28, the leap is phenomenal. From selling khaini (raw tobacco) at his father’s small time shop in Nawada district, he has made it to the coveted civil services, the results of which were declared on Wednesday.
Belonging to a small village, Pakri Barawan in Nawada district, 100 km south of Patna, Niranjan is not ashamed of his humble background.
“I used to sit at my father’s small shop and sell khaini when he would go out. My father still runs the shop, even as I tell him he doesn’t need to anymore for a monthly earning of Rs 5,000,” says Niranjan.
Niranjan remembers the struggles he had to overcome in life to achieve what he has.
“Coming from a poor background, my father did not have enough money for the education of his children – three sons and a daughter. I successfully took the written test for admission to the Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya in Nawada, for the simple reason that education was free there,” he recollects.
Having done his matriculation from Nawada in 2004, he moved to Science College, Patna, for his intermediate level education in 2006.
“Even to pay the tuition fee of Rs 1,200 for two years was not easy for me. I used to walk 8-10 kms every day for my coaching classes. Later, after one-and-a-half years, I bought a second hand bicycle with Rs 600, which I saved by imparting tuitions to children, while staying with my uncle in Patna to pursue my intermediate studies,” he recalls.
Niranjan went on to compete in IIT-ISM, Dhanbad for mining engineering course. He took an education loan of Rs 4 lakh from bank that he repaid after joining the Coal India Limited as an assistant engineer (mining) in 2011.
Married to Nupur Gupta, an illustrator and digital designer, with whom he fell in love with, they have a one-month old daughter, Shaanvi. His father, Arvind Kumar, 60 and mother, Yashoda Devi, 55 are proud of their son’s achievement.
Niranjan is not satisfied with his 728th rank in civil services. “I will get Indian Revenue Service (he belongs to the OBC category), but will write the UPSC civil services exams next year again because my target is to make the IAS,” he signs off.
Niranjan is among the 35-odd from Bihar who have made the cut in the civil services-2016 exams. Six of them — Utsav Kaushal (14th rank) Somesh Kumar Upadhyay (34th), Prema Dikshit (57th), Soumya Jha (58th), Aarif Ehsaan (74th) and Shashi Prakash Singh (75th rank) are in top 100 in the list of 1099 successful candidates pan India.

Six Indian Institutes of Technology (IIT) got new directors on Thursday, according to sources in the Education Ministry. While Mr Manindra Agrawal has been appointed as the director of IIT-Kanpur, Mr Devendra Jalihal of IIT-Madras has been appointed as the director of IIT-Guwahati, they said. Mr Agrawal was a professor at IIT-Kanpur's Department of Computer Science and Engineering. "Mr Avinash Kumar Agarwal, professor at IIT-Kanpur's Department of Mechanical Engineering, has been appointed as the director of IIT-Jodhpur," a source said. "Mr Sukumar Mishra has been appointed as the director of IIT-Dhanbad while Mr DS Katti will be the new head of IIT-Goa," the source added. Mr Amit Patra has been appointed as the director of IIT-BHU.
(This story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)
Track Education News , Exam updates , Campus , Study Abroad related news live on NDTV.com

JEE Advanced: The cut-offs for the Electrical Engineering department have seen a significant change at IIT Dhanbad . The opening cut off for the first round of counselling in the open category was between 3000 to 3700 from 2019 to 2021. However, over the last two years, the opening rank for the category has been over 5000.
As per the data available, the opening rank for open category females has been around 10,000 for the last few years. The opening rank for EWS category also increased from 476 in 2019 to 934 in 2023. Similar trends have been seen across all other categories.
The institute secured 42nd rank in the overall category of National Institutional Ranking Framework (NIRF) 2023 , it ranked 17 amongst engineering colleges, 24 in the research category and 44 in the management colleges category.
Given below are the last five years’ cut-offs for admissions to Electrical Engineering (4 years, Bachelor of Technology):
Electronics Engineering was introduced here in 1977, even though the institute was established in 1926 by Viceroy Lord Irwin as Indian School of Mines and Applied Geology at Dhanbad. It offers several courses such as BTech, dual degree, Integrated MSc,  Integrated MSc, MTech, MPhil and MBA.
The institute began admitting students through Joint Entrance Examination (JEE), conducted jointly by the IIT’s and ISM, in 1997. It became an IIT on September 6, 2016.
The Law Commission has determined that the simultaneous elections Bills are constitutional and do not need state ratification. They do not impact voting rights or government accountability. The Model Code of Conduct does not need statutory recognition. However, the commission opposes a constructive no-confidence vote and codifying the poll code.

THE UNION Ministry of Education on Thursday appointed new directors to six IITs across the country. Manindra Agrawal, Sukumar Mishra, Avinash Agarwal, Dr Devendra Jalihal, Dhirendra S Katti and Amit Patra will take up the position of directors at IIT-Kanpur, Dhanbad, Jodhpur, Guwahati, Goa and IIT-BHU, respectively.
Agrawal, the new IIT-Kanpur director, has been a professor at department of computer science and engineering at the same institute since 1996. His teaching areas include algorithms, complexity theory, computational number theory and algebra and cryptography. His notable achievements include a Padma Shri in 2013; he was also a Humboldt fellow at the University of Ulm in Germany, 1995-96.
Mishra, who has been appointed as director, IIT-Dhanbad, was a professor in the department of electrical engineering at IIT- Delhi . He is currently serving as dean, research and external engagement, IIT-Delhi-Abu Dhabi campus. He also worked as associate dean, R&D of IIT-Delhi from March 1, 2020 to March 31, 2023.
Avinash Agarwal, who has been appointed to IIT-Jodhpur, one of the new generation IITs, was serving as a professor at the department of mechanical engineering in IIT-Kanpur.
Jalihal, new IIT- Guwahati director, was serving as a professor at IIT-Madras in the department of electrical engineering. As per his profile, his research interests include signal processing and wireless communication. He has been at IIT-Madras since 2006.
Katti was a professor at IIT-Kanpur’s biological sciences and bioengineering department; he will now serve as director at IIT-Goa. He received his Ph.D from University of Mumbai and his post-doctoral training from Drexel University, USA. He served as an assistant professor (research track) at Drexel University and then as assistant professor (tenure track) at University of Virginia before joining the BSBE department in April, 2004.
Patra, who was serving as the Deputy Director  at IIT Kharagpur has now been appointed as Director at IIT BHU . He received the B.Tech., M.Tech. and Ph.D. degrees from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur in 1984, 1986 and 1990 respectively. He joined the Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur in 1987 as a faculty member.
The Law Commission has determined that the simultaneous elections Bills are constitutional and do not need state ratification. They do not impact voting rights or government accountability. The Model Code of Conduct does not need statutory recognition. However, the commission opposes a constructive no-confidence vote and codifying the poll code.

Six Indian Institutes of Technology (IIT) got new directors on Thursday, according to sources in the education ministry. While Manindra Agrawal has been appointed as the director of IIT-Kanpur, Devendra Jalihal of IIT-Madras has been appointed as the director of IIT-Guwahati, they said.
Agrawal was a professor at IIT-Kanpur's Department of Computer Science and Engineering. "Avinash Kumar Agarwal, professor at IIT-Kanpur's Department of Mechanical Engineering, has been appointed as the director of IIT-Jodhpur," a source said.
"Sukumar Mishra has been appointed as the director of IIT-Dhanbad while DS Katti will be the new head of IIT-Goa," the source added. Amit Patra has been appointed as the director of IIT-BHU.

After Mission Mangal and Kesari, actor Akshay Kumar is on a new mission in his upcoming film, Mission Raniganj: The Great Bharat Rescue. He will be reprising the role of mining expert, Jaswant Singh Gill in the film, written by Vipul K Rawal and directed by Tinu Suresh Desai. The trailer of the film offered a glimpse into the real story of Gill rescuing 65 miners from a flooded mine in Raniganj, West Bengal.
What makes the incident important? Why did people celebrate Gill after the rescue mission, and why did he win ‘Sarvottam Jeevan Raksha Padak’ from the then President of India, Ramaswamy Venkataraman? The indianexpress.com explains.
Born in Amritsar in 1940, Jaswant Singh Gill studied at Khalsa School and later took admission in BSc (non-medical) at Khalsa College (Amritsar). He studied BSc (Honours) from the Indian School of Mines, Dhanbad, before joining Coal India Limited in 1973. Throughout his tenure, he kept growing in ranks from 1-9 and ultimately retired in 1998 as Engineer-in-chief. The most significant event of his over two-decade career was the rescue mission at the Mahabir Colliery, Raniganj, West Bengal. He saved the lives of 65 miners who were trapped in a flooded coal mine. He also got the moniker of Capsule Gill after the incident.
On November 13, 1989, 232 miners were employed in the night shift to work towards the rise-most area of the 320-foot-deep mine to excavate coal through explosions. At around 4 am, there was a sudden influx of water, and the mine got flooded. The 161 miners who were near the two lifts in the pit could be rescued immediately, but 71 of them were far off and couldn’t reach the lift due to the water. Fortunately, there was a telephone connection between the borehole and the surface, through which a message was sent that 65 miners had taken shelter at a rise part of the pit, but six of them had gone missing.
On learning about the trapped miners, the authorities formed four teams to rescue them. Three out of the four teams started trying various methods to bring out the miners. Several submersible pumps were inserted in the mine to reduce the water level, but the water kept recirculating inside the mine and the pumped-out water was finding its way back through cracks in the surface. Meanwhile, the oxygen level in the mine was depleting too, and the mine could collapse at any time.
Senior engineer Jasawant Gill, who was a part of the fourth team, came up with an idea that nobody could have imagined. “My father started to innovate on a theoretical idea that had never been put to practical use. It involved fabricating a steel capsule about 7 feet high and 22 inches in diameter, creating a new borehole to lower the capsule into the mine and taking out the miners, one by one,” Sarpreet Singh Gill, son of Jaswant Gill, shared with The Tribune.
The steel capsule was constructed in 72 hours and after a few trial runs up and down the borehole, rescue of men began on November 16 at 2.30 am. Gill insisted on going into the capsule himself to bring out the trapped men. After initial opposition from the top officials of Coal India Limited, Gill entered the capsule and brought out all of the 65 men one by one by 8:30 am. Initially, it took 15 minutes for one round trip of the capsule. So, a 12-tonne crane was put into service for lowering and raising the capsule and this reduced the cycle time to just 3 minutes.
There were 20,000 people who gathered to witness the rescue operation in Raniganj. “It took me six hours to bring up the 65 miners one by one and last of all, when I emerged from the capsule, people went mad with joy,” Gill once shared with The Tribune. He added that the moment he came out, people lifted him on his shoulders and put garlands around his neck.
How was Jaswant Singh Gill rewarded for his act of bravery?
To celebrate Gill’s act of bravery, Coal India Ltd announced November 16 as ‘Rescue Day’. Limca Book of Records has certified this operation as a national record in the history of coal mining.
Gill was also honoured with the highest civilian bravery award, ‘Sarvottam Jeevan Raksha Padak’ by President Ramaswamy Venkataraman in 1991.
Until his death in 2019, Gill remained active in his social welfare work.

The Union Cabinet approved giving IIT status to the Indian School of Mines (ISM) Dhanbad on Wednesday in a move that had been a long time in coming.
Col (Retd) MK Singh, Registrar ISM, while appreciating the response of the government, said, Prime Minister has done whatever he had promised during the Lok Sabha elections. “We are very thankful to the Prime Minister and Union HRD minister for giving enormous attention and respect to our institution,” said the registrar.
Similarly, students too welcomed the development.
ISM had been fighting for an IIT tag since 2013.
The institute was promised it would get the label so that it gets better placement opportunities, more research funds from the government, better opportunities for international collaborations, and a positive change in perception.
Last year, several students of the premiere institute had also taken to the streets against the delay in the upgrade.
Over one thousand students had demonstrated at Jantar Mantar in New Delhi in 2013 and got huge support from the political leaders especially MPs across the country.
The institute was formally opened on December 9, 1926, by Lord Irwin, the then Viceroy of India to address the need for trained manpower related to mining activities in the country with disciplines of Mining and Applied Geology.
Earlier on April 8, Union HRD minister Smriti Irani on her visit to ISM had assured students an IIT tag would be announced soon.

The Indian Institute of Technology, Dhanbad (IIT (ISM) Dhanbad), formerly known as the Indian School of Mines, is an autonomous technical institute located in Jharkhand, India. The institute was established in 1926. IIT (ISM) Dhanbad is ranked #15 in the engineering category and ranked #46 in the management category by NIRF Ranking 2024 .
The flagship course offered by IIT (ISM) Dhanbad is the B.Tech program. IIT (ISM) Dhanbad B.Tech admission requires a Higher Secondary Certificate degree (10+2) with at least 75% marks. Applicants need a valid national-level examination ( JEE Advanced ) scorecard. Seats are allocated by a separate centralised counselling process through the Joint Seat Allocation Authority (JoSSA).
The tuition fee for the B.Tech program is INR 1,00,000 per semester for the GEN/OBC-NCL/EWS category. Whereas, applicants from the SC/ST/PwD category are exempted from paying the tuition fees.
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad placement As of October 16, 2024, IIT Dhanbad recorded 1,114 job offers, including 184 Pre-Placement Offers (PPOs) and 11 international offers. A total of 865 male and 225 female students were placed, along with 8 PhD students securing jobs. Top recruiters like Dublin, Google, Amazon, Oracle, ONGC, TCS, Mahindra, Bajaj, Jaguar, Walmart, Intel, Cognizant, Microsoft, etc.
Dublin, Google, Amazon, Oracle, ONGC, TCS, Mahindra, Bajaj, Jaguar, Walmart, Intel, Cognizant, Microsoft
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad offers undergraduate, postgraduate, and doctoral programs in disciplines like engineering, architecture, management, basic sciences, humanities, social sciences, etc. A course-wise detailed list of eligibility criteria and tuition fees is mentioned below:
SC/ST candidates are exempted from tuition fees
B.Tech degree with minimum 55% marks
SC/ST candidates are exempted from tuition fees
B.Tech degree in  any relevant discipline in Engineering/M.Sc.
SC/SCT/PWD/PH candidates are exempted from tuition fees
Graduation degree with 55% (GEN/EWS/OBC), whereas 50% marks (SC/ST/PwD)
SC/ST candidates are exempted from tuition fees
Graduation degree with 60% (GEN/EWS/OBC), whereas 55% marks (SC/ST/PwD)  + 2 years of Industrial experience
SC/ST candidates are exempted from tuition fees
Master's degree in a relevant discipline with a minimum of 60% marks or equivalent
SC/ST candidates are exempted from tuition fees
For IIT (ISM) Dhanbad admission ,  applicants will require a national-level entrance (JEE Advanced/GATE/IIT JAM) score followed by a counselling process (JoSSA/CCMT). A course-wise list of selection criteria is given below:
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad offers four-year undergraduate programs in Mining Engineering, Civil Engineering, Electronics and Communication Engineering, Computer Science and Engineering, etc. The institute also offers a five-year B.Tech + M.Tech dual program degree in Applied Geology, Applied Geophysics, and Mathematics and Computing.
To be eligible for the JEE Advanced exam, candidates must rank among the top 2,50,000 scorers in the B.E./B.Tech. paper of the JEE Main exam , regardless of category. The top 2,50,000 candidates from each category will be selected based on their performance on the B.E./B.Tech. paper. Seats will be allocated to candidates from different categories based on the following percentages: 10% for GEN-EWS, 27% for OBC-NCL, 15% for SC, 7.5% for ST, and 40.5% OPEN. Within each category, 5% of seats are reserved for the PWD candidates.
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad offers a two-year master’s degree in 19 specialisations in Electrical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Mining Engineering, Electronic and Communication Engineering, etc. Registration has already started for the upcoming GATE 2025 exam .
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad offers a two-year master’s program in chemistry, physics, maths, and computing. In addition to this, the institute also provides a three-year master’s program in Applied Geophysics and Applied Geology. The selection criteria will be based on the IIT JAM score followed by JOAPS counselling. Registration for IIT JAM has already started for the upcoming year.
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad offers other valuable courses like the two-year MBA program in Business Analytics. The procedure for selection will be based on national-level exams like CAT followed by a personal interview. The important dates for CAT 2025 exam is mentioned below:
Application process starting date
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad offers a doctoral degree in full-time mode. For this candidate should qualify institute’s entrance tests followed by a personal interview. However, candidates who have already qualified for GATE/ UGC /DST/ CSIR-NET exams are exempted from taking the institute’s entrance test, but they need to sit for the interview. On the other hand, for management students, a valid CAT/GMAT score is required followed by an interview.
The institute also allows direct Ph.D. admission for its M.Sc. Tech. and M.Sc. students. For this 20% of candidates who have obtained a CGPA of 8.5 and above are eligible to apply.
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad has yet to release the JEE Main and GATE cutoff for 2025. Based on this score, candidates will be called for the final counselling round.
NTA has officially released the JEE Main cutoff for 2024. The JEE Main cutoffs for other courses are given below:
NTA has officially released the JEE Main cutoff for 2023. The JEE Main cutoffs for other courses are given below:
Electronics and Communication Engineering
Mineral and Metallurgical Engineering
GATE 2024 cutoff has been officially released.A category-wise cutoff for other courses are mentioned below:
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad's cutoff for CSE is 664 for open-category students. A category-wise cutoff for other courses are mentioned below:
Computer Science and Engineering
Electronics and Communication Engineering
As of October 16, 2024, IIT Dhanbad recorded 1,114 job offers, including 184 Pre-Placement Offers (PPOs) and 11 international offers. A total of 865 male and 225 female students were placed, along with 8 PhD students securing jobs.
As per NIRF ranking 2024 IIT (ISM) Dhanbad secured the 15th position for its engineering category.
For admission to the B.Tech program at IIT (ISM) Dhanbad, the candidate must have a higher secondary degree (10+2) with at least 75% marks. The selection process will be based on the JEE Advanced score.
The tuition fee for the B.Tech program at IIT (ISM) Dhanbad is INR 1,00,000/semester for GEN/EWS/OBC-NCL category candidates.
As per AICTE’s approval, IIT (ISM) Dhanbad in 2021-22 admitted 3579 (2951 males and 628 females) students under B.Tech program.
The tuition fee for the M.Tech program is INR 15,000 per semester at IIT (ISM) Dhanbad.
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad CSE 2023 All India closing rank is 3258 in round 6 of JoSSA counselling.
The highest and average CTC is INR 83 LPA and INR 17 LPA at at the IIT (ISM) Dhanbad in 2023.
IIT (ISM) Dhanbad All India's closing rank for B.Tech in Electronics and Communication Engineering is 5250.
Top recruiters who participated in the placement session at IIT (ISM) Dhanbad included Dublin, Google, Amazon, Oracle, ONGC, TCS, Mahindra, Bajaj, Jaguar, Walmart, Intel, Cognizant, Microsoft, etc.

Engineers’ Day 2023: The concept of the Indian Institutes of Technology (IIT) was first introduced in the year 1945 in a report by NM Sircar, then a member of Education on Viceroy’s Executive Council.
In 1946, a committee was set by Sir Jogendra Singh, member of the Viceroy’s Executive Council, Department of Education, Health and Agriculture to consider setting up of Higher Technical Institutions for post war Industrial Development in India. The committee, headed by NR Sarkar, recommended the establishment of four higher technical institutions in eastern, western, northern and southern regions, possibly on the lines of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), USA. The report also urged the government to establish the institutions in East and West, to be started immediately.
The committee believed that the aim of these institutes should not be limited to producing engineering graduates, and IITs should also focus on research, producing research workers and technical teachers. The committee wanted to match the international standards in research. They aimed to have the proportion of undergraduates and postgraduate students as 2:1.
The institute was given the title of Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) on September 21, 2001 but the history of the college is nearly 175 years old.
IIT Roorkee originally began as a training school at Saharanpur in 1845 and was called Thomason College of Engineering from 1847 to 1947. On September 21, 1853, the college was renamed Thomason College of Civil Engineering. The entrance test for college began in 1857. In 1864, the Roorkee College was affiliated to Calcutta University. In 1905, the affiliation to Allahabad University ended.
In 1948, Roorkee University Act was passed by the provincial legislature and in 1949, Thomason College was elevated to university status.
IIT BHU was established in 1919. The institutes started with the establishment of Banaras Engineering College (BENCO), and the next stage saw the establishment of the College of Technology (TECHNO) and the College of Mining and Metallurgy (MINMET). With time, it merged to form the Institute of Technology (IT-BHU).
On June 29, 2012, the institute became IIT (BHU) Varanasi by an Act of Parliament. The over 100-year-old institute was established by Pandit Madan Mohan Malviya.
In December 1901, a resolution by the Indian National Congress at its XVII session stated that: “In view of the fact that the tendency of recent legislation namely, The Indian Mines Act VII of 1901, is that all Indian mines must be kept under the supervision of mining experts.”
The Indian School of Mines and Applied Geology at Dhanbad was established by the then Viceroy Lord Irwin on December 9, 1926. In 1996-97, the Indian government took over the control of the institute. On September 6, 2016, the Indian School of Mines (ISM) became the Indian Institute of Technology, Dhanbad.
In 1956, the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany offered assistance to establish a higher technological institute in India. It resulted in the signing of the first Indo-German Agreement in Bonn in 1959 to establish IIT Madras. The Institute was formally inaugurated in 1959 by professor Humayun Kabir, then Union Minister for Scientific and Cultural Affairs.
IIT Delhi was established as College of Engineering in 1961 and later declared as an Institution of National Importance under the ‘Institutes of Technology (Amendment) Act, 1963’ and renamed as IIT Delhi. IIT Delhi is a collaboration with the Government of the UK. The then Indian government negotiated with the British government to set up IIT Delhi.
Established in 1958, it was the second IIT in the country. It was the first to be set up with foreign assistance receiving funds from UNESCO, it came as Roubles from the then Soviet Union. In 1961, the Parliament decreed the IITs as ‘Institutes of National Importance’.
The Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur was established by the government in 1959. It began its operations in a borrowed building of Harcourt Butler Technological Institute with 100 students. Today, the institute has its own residential campus for about 2255 undergraduate and 1476 postgraduate students, 309 faculty members and over 900 supporting staff members.
The Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur was the first IIT to be established in the country. It was established in May 1950 in Hijli, Kharagpur. In the first batch (August 1951), there were 224 freshers and 42 teachers.
The institute was given the title of Indian Institute of Technology on September 21, 2001. In December 2001, Dr Prem Vrat took charge as the director of IIT Roorkee. In October 2022, Professor Kamal Kishore Pant took charge as director.
Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati is the sixth member of the IIT fraternity. It was established in 1994 and the academic programme commenced in 1995.
Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad (IITH) was established in 2008. It offers undergraduate programmes in engineering disciplines, applied sciences, and design as well several interdisciplinary areas. There are separate programmes for technology, design, science and liberal arts.
IIT Gandhinagar was founded in 2008 and is located in Palaj, Gandhinagar (Gujarat) on the banks of River Sabarmati. It is India’s first five-star GRIHA LD (Green) campus for minimising the negative impact on the environment.
IIT Indore was established in 2009. The institute started functioning from a temporary campus at the Institute of Engineering and Technology of Devi Ahilya University under the mentorship of IIT Bombay in 2009–10.
The Indian School of Mines and Applied Geology at Dhanbad was established by the hands of the then Viceroy Lord Irwin on December 9, 1926.
The Law Commission has determined that the simultaneous elections Bills are constitutional and do not need state ratification. They do not impact voting rights or government accountability. The Model Code of Conduct does not need statutory recognition. However, the commission opposes a constructive no-confidence vote and codifying the poll code.

On June 29, 2012, the institute became IIT (BHU) Varanasi by an Act of Parliament. The over 100-year-old institute was established by Pandit Madan Mohan Malviya.
In December 1901, a resolution by the Indian National Congress at its XVII session stated that: “In view of the fact that the tendency of recent legislation namely, The Indian Mines Act VII of 1901, is that all Indian mines must be kept under the supervision of mining experts.”
The Indian School of Mines and Applied Geology at Dhanbad was established by the then Viceroy Lord Irwin on December 9, 1926. In 1996-97, the Indian government took over the control of the institute. On September 6, 2016, the Indian School of Mines (ISM) became the Indian Institute of Technology, Dhanbad.
In 1956, the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany offered assistance to establish a higher technological institute in India. It resulted in the signing of the first Indo-German Agreement in Bonn in 1959 to establish IIT Madras. The Institute was formally inaugurated in 1959 by professor Humayun Kabir, then Union Minister for Scientific and Cultural Affairs.
IIT Delhi was established as College of Engineering in 1961 and later declared as an Institution of National Importance under the ‘Institutes of Technology (Amendment) Act, 1963’ and renamed as IIT Delhi. IIT Delhi is a collaboration with the Government of the UK. The then Indian government negotiated with the British government to set up IIT Delhi.
Established in 1958, it was the second IIT in the country. It was the first to be set up with foreign assistance receiving funds from UNESCO, it came as Roubles from the then Soviet Union. In 1961, the Parliament decreed the IITs as ‘Institutes of National Importance’.
The Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur was established by the government in 1959. It began its operations in a borrowed building of Harcourt Butler Technological Institute with 100 students. Today, the institute has its own residential campus for about 2255 undergraduate and 1476 postgraduate students, 309 faculty members and over 900 supporting staff members.
The Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur was the first IIT to be established in the country. It was established in May 1950 in Hijli, Kharagpur. In the first batch (August 1951), there were 224 freshers and 42 teachers.
The institute was given the title of Indian Institute of Technology on September 21, 2001. In December 2001, Dr Prem Vrat took charge as the director of IIT Roorkee. In October 2022, Professor Kamal Kishore Pant took charge as director.
Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati is the sixth member of the IIT fraternity. It was established in 1994 and the academic programme commenced in 1995.
Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad (IITH) was established in 2008. It offers undergraduate programmes in engineering disciplines, applied sciences, and design as well several interdisciplinary areas. There are separate programmes for technology, design, science and liberal arts.
IIT Gandhinagar was founded in 2008 and is located in Palaj, Gandhinagar (Gujarat) on the banks of River Sabarmati. It is India’s first five-star GRIHA LD (Green) campus for minimising the negative impact on the environment.
IIT Indore was established in 2009. The institute started functioning from a temporary campus at the Institute of Engineering and Technology of Devi Ahilya University under the mentorship of IIT Bombay in 2009–10.
The Indian School of Mines and Applied Geology at Dhanbad was established by the hands of the then Viceroy Lord Irwin on December 9, 1926.
The Law Commission has determined that the simultaneous elections Bills are constitutional and do not need state ratification. They do not impact voting rights or government accountability. The Model Code of Conduct does not need statutory recognition. However, the commission opposes a constructive no-confidence vote and codifying the poll code.

Campus_Infrastructure.text_content:
Subscribe Now! Get features like
Two students of Jharkhand's Indian School of Mines (ISM) drowned after skidding into Bhatinda Falls on Saturday while taking selfie. The students were on picnic at the waterfall, around 40 kilometres from Dhanbad.
They have been identified as Arun Kumar Singh, a third year computer science student and resident of Sonbhadra in Uttar Pradesh and Lawansh Sharma, a third year electrical engineering student from Madhya Pradesh.
According to police and college authorities, the two, who were part of a four-member team of picnickers to Bhatinda Falls, were residing at Amber hostel.
At the spot , Lavansh Sharma reportedly entered the restricted area to take selfie and slipped into the waterfall. Watching him struggle in the waters, Arun Kumar Singh jumped after him but he drowned too. Their companions, Ayush Kumar and Gopal Sharma, cried for help but in vain, said D Prasad, officer-in-charge of Putki police station.
He said the police’s first priority was to retrieve the bodies. However, there was no success till late evening. The ISM administration too has sent a team led by its security officer Rahul Kumar to the spot “to recover the bodies of our students at the earliest,” said ISM registrat Col (Retd) MK Singh.
In a similar incident in November 2011, two students of the college, Guturvira Ashok and Nand Dayal Gautam, had drowned in the waterfall while bathing.

Notable_Alumni.text_content:
After Mission Mangal and Kesari, actor Akshay Kumar is on a new mission in his upcoming film, Mission Raniganj: The Great Bharat Rescue. He will be reprising the role of mining expert, Jaswant Singh Gill in the film, written by Vipul K Rawal and directed by Tinu Suresh Desai. The trailer of the film offered a glimpse into the real story of Gill rescuing 65 miners from a flooded mine in Raniganj, West Bengal.
What makes the incident important? Why did people celebrate Gill after the rescue mission, and why did he win ‘Sarvottam Jeevan Raksha Padak’ from the then President of India, Ramaswamy Venkataraman? The indianexpress.com explains.
Born in Amritsar in 1940, Jaswant Singh Gill studied at Khalsa School and later took admission in BSc (non-medical) at Khalsa College (Amritsar). He studied BSc (Honours) from the Indian School of Mines, Dhanbad, before joining Coal India Limited in 1973. Throughout his tenure, he kept growing in ranks from 1-9 and ultimately retired in 1998 as Engineer-in-chief. The most significant event of his over two-decade career was the rescue mission at the Mahabir Colliery, Raniganj, West Bengal. He saved the lives of 65 miners who were trapped in a flooded coal mine. He also got the moniker of Capsule Gill after the incident.
On November 13, 1989, 232 miners were employed in the night shift to work towards the rise-most area of the 320-foot-deep mine to excavate coal through explosions. At around 4 am, there was a sudden influx of water, and the mine got flooded. The 161 miners who were near the two lifts in the pit could be rescued immediately, but 71 of them were far off and couldn’t reach the lift due to the water. Fortunately, there was a telephone connection between the borehole and the surface, through which a message was sent that 65 miners had taken shelter at a rise part of the pit, but six of them had gone missing.
On learning about the trapped miners, the authorities formed four teams to rescue them. Three out of the four teams started trying various methods to bring out the miners. Several submersible pumps were inserted in the mine to reduce the water level, but the water kept recirculating inside the mine and the pumped-out water was finding its way back through cracks in the surface. Meanwhile, the oxygen level in the mine was depleting too, and the mine could collapse at any time.
Senior engineer Jasawant Gill, who was a part of the fourth team, came up with an idea that nobody could have imagined. “My father started to innovate on a theoretical idea that had never been put to practical use. It involved fabricating a steel capsule about 7 feet high and 22 inches in diameter, creating a new borehole to lower the capsule into the mine and taking out the miners, one by one,” Sarpreet Singh Gill, son of Jaswant Gill, shared with The Tribune.
The steel capsule was constructed in 72 hours and after a few trial runs up and down the borehole, rescue of men began on November 16 at 2.30 am. Gill insisted on going into the capsule himself to bring out the trapped men. After initial opposition from the top officials of Coal India Limited, Gill entered the capsule and brought out all of the 65 men one by one by 8:30 am. Initially, it took 15 minutes for one round trip of the capsule. So, a 12-tonne crane was put into service for lowering and raising the capsule and this reduced the cycle time to just 3 minutes.
There were 20,000 people who gathered to witness the rescue operation in Raniganj. “It took me six hours to bring up the 65 miners one by one and last of all, when I emerged from the capsule, people went mad with joy,” Gill once shared with The Tribune. He added that the moment he came out, people lifted him on his shoulders and put garlands around his neck.
How was Jaswant Singh Gill rewarded for his act of bravery?
To celebrate Gill’s act of bravery, Coal India Ltd announced November 16 as ‘Rescue Day’. Limca Book of Records has certified this operation as a national record in the history of coal mining.
Gill was also honoured with the highest civilian bravery award, ‘Sarvottam Jeevan Raksha Padak’ by President Ramaswamy Venkataraman in 1991.
Until his death in 2019, Gill remained active in his social welfare work.
Click here to follow Screen Digital on YouTube and stay updated with the latest from the world of cinema.
The Law Commission has determined that the simultaneous elections Bills are constitutional and do not need state ratification. They do not impact voting rights or government accountability. The Model Code of Conduct does not need statutory recognition. However, the commission opposes a constructive no-confidence vote and codifying the poll code.

Born on November 22, 1937, Jaswant Gill hailed from Sathiala in Amritsar, Punjab. He pursued his engineering in Mining Engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology ISM Dhanbad. 1965 Batch, Mining Engineering. Gill, whose passing occurred on November 26, 2019, made a substantial contribution to the rescue efforts during the 1989 incident in Raniganj, West Bengal when miners were trapped inside a flooded coal mine.
On November 23, 1989, in Raniganj, West Bengal, 220 miners were engaged in their routine task of excavating coal through controlled explosions. Unfortunately, the region was experiencing severe flooding at the time. In an unfortunate accident, someone inadvertently disturbed the upper layer of the mine, leading to a sudden influx of water.
While a significant number of workers successfully evacuated the mine using two lifts, 71 miners found themselves trapped as the mine shafts became inundated with water. Tragically, six individuals lost their lives in the incident, leaving 65 miners trapped underground.
During that period, Jaswant Singh Gill held the position of additional chief mining engineer at the mine. Upon learning of the tragic situation where 65 lives were hanging in the balance, Jaswant Gill acted swiftly and without hesitation. He ventured into the borewell and undertook the remarkable task of rescuing the trapped miners single-handedly.
He took charge of the entire rescue operation, devising a strategic plan that included the ingenious concept of constructing a steel capsule capable of transporting one person at a time through the borewell.
Jaswant Singh Gill's extraordinary act of valor elevated him to the status of a national hero. In recognition of his selfless heroism, then-President of India, Ramaswamy Venkataraman, bestowed upon him the prestigious 'Sarvottam Jeevan Raksha Padak' in 1991. Furthermore, in honor of his bravery and dedication, a square on Majitha Road in Punjab was dedicated and named after him.
And now, Bollywood superstar Akshay Kumar is all set to launch his upcoming film, "Mission Raniganj," which is centered on the Raniganj Coalfields collapse of 1989.

Actor Akshay Kumar will next be seen in Mission Raniganj, where he plays the role of late coal mine engineer Jaswant Singh Gill. Remembering his meeting with Jaswant, Akshay described him as a “humble” and “simple” person.
During a virtual interaction with students of the Indian Institute of Technology (Indian School of Mines), Dhanbad, Akshay spoke about the importance of telling stories of unsung heroes. He said, “A few years ago, I had the opportunity to talk on a call with Jaswantji when he was alive. He was so humble, simple, and down to earth that it was genuinely an honour talking to him. There’s so much truth and sacrifice in the inspiring stories of such unsung heroes that I would like to keep making films like that and tell today’s youth about such great visionaries.” Jaswant Singh Gill graduated from IIT Dhanbad.
Akshay Kumar is known for doing films with a social message. Akshay has starred in Padman, based on social activist Arunachalam Muruganantham. He also did the film Toilet: Ek Prem Katha, which dealt with the health hazard of open defecation.
Talking about being part of ‘inspirational stories’, Akshay said, “Jaswant Gill’s real-life story is truly inspiring and encouraging. Similarly, Padman also showcased the inspiring journey of a visionary. They don’t make people like them anymore. As an actor, I really love working on such inspirational stories that need to be told.”
In 1989, Jaswant Singh Gill led a rescue mission that saved 64 people trapped in a coal mine in West Bengal’s Raniganj. Mission Raniganj also stars Parineeti Chopra in the lead role and is directed by Tinu Suresh Desai. The film will release in theatres on October 6.
Click here to follow Screen Digital on YouTube and stay updated with the latest from the world of cinema.
The Law Commission has determined that the simultaneous elections Bills are constitutional and do not need state ratification. They do not impact voting rights or government accountability. The Model Code of Conduct does not need statutory recognition. However, the commission opposes a constructive no-confidence vote and codifying the poll code.

Milestones_and_Evolution.text_content:
There are 23 Indian Institute of Technology (IITs) in India. The first preference of any candidate who appears for the JEE Mains is always IIT. The Indian Institute of Technology offers a wide range of engineering courses like Computer Science Engineering, B.Tech in general engineering, Artificial Intelligence and Data Engineering. Candidates who have secured ranks within the cutoff can easily apply to their dream IIT. In 2025, a total of 12,58,136 candidates appeared for the JEE Mains exams. The details of the top 20 IITs according to the NIRF Ranking are given below:
The Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IITM) was set up in 1956 by the German Government. The first Indo-German agreement in Bonn, West Germany, for the establishment of the Indian Institute of Technology at Madras was signed in 1959. IIT Madras has 550 faculty members, 8000 students, and 1250 administrative & supporting staff. The campus is spread over 250 hectares. The Institute has 16 academic departments and advanced research centres, along with 100 laboratories.
Indian Institute of Technology Delhi (IIT Delhi) was established in 1961 as the College of Engineering, was later declared an Institution of National Importance in 1963. It gained Deemed University status, which granted it autonomy in academics and degree awarding. Over 60,000 students have graduated from IIT Delhi across Engineering, Sciences, Management, and Humanities, including over 5,000 Ph.D. holders and 15,738 B.Tech graduates. The alumni have excelled globally as scientists, technologists, entrepreneurs, and leaders in diverse sectors, contributing significantly to national development and global industrialization.
The Indian Institute of Technology Bombay (IIT Bombay) was established in 1958 in Powai, Mumbai, one of India’s premier engineering institutions. The institute attracts meritorious students and has faculty engaged in pioneering research and academic collaborations globally. Governed by a Board of Governors and guided by the IIT Council under the Ministry of Education, IIT Bombay offers a fully residential campus, short-term and continuing education programs, and has produced alumni who have excelled in diverse fields worldwide.
The Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur (IIT Kanpur), founded in 1959 by the Government of India, is one of the nation’s leading institutions for higher learning and scientific research in science, technology, and engineering. Inspired by a mission to create, disseminate, and apply knowledge for the betterment of society, the institute fosters excellence through a vibrant academic environment, state-of-the-art research, and industry linkage. With a residential campus area of 1,055 acres, IIT Kanpur welcomes more than 8,500 students and 555 teachers. It boasts a rich legacy of international engagement, such as the Kanpur Indo-American Programme, and continues to foster innovation, leadership, and ethical values.
The Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur (IIT Kharagpur) was founded in 1951. IIT KGP is the oldest IITs. It has a vast 2,100-acre campus spread across West Bengal and provides a complete array of undergraduate, postgraduate, and doctoral courses in the fields of engineering, sciences, management, law, and humanities. The institute is famous for its quality of education, state-of-the-art research, and lively campus life. Ranked among India’s top engineering institutions by NIRF and QS rankings.
The Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee (IIT Roorkee) was founded in 1847. It has a campus across 365 acres in the state of Uttarakhand and has more than 8,000 students across 23 departments. It is ranked 6th in Engineering and 8th in overall NIRF 2024 rankings. The institute had 1,200+ placements in 2023, with leading domestic offers of over ₹1.3 crore. It has top events such as Thomso and Cognizance and fosters innovation through TIDES and international collaborations.
Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati (IIT Guwahati) was founded in 1994. It is a leading technical institution on a 700-acre campus on the banks of the Brahmaputra River. Ranked 7th in Engineering and 9th Overall in NIRF 2024, it accommodates more than 8,000 students and 500+ faculty members. The placements in 2025 had offers ranging up to ₹2.10 crore and a median CSE package of ₹34.5 LPA. Popular for research centers of high sophistication and Asia’s 124th QS ranking, it is a center of excellence and innovation.
The Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad (IIT Hyderabad) was founded in 2008. It has a campus spread over 576 acres in the Sangareddy district, Telangana. It has a student-faculty ratio of 14:1. During the 2024 placement season, more than 70% of students were placed with over 522 offers, the best package going up to ₹90 LPA, with an average package of ₹22.5 LPA.
The Indian Institute of Technology Varanasi (IIT-BHU – Varanasi ) was established in 1919. The institute was formerly known as the Banaras Engineering College (BENCO).
The Indian Institute of Technology (Indian School of Mines) Dhanbad was established in 1926 as ISM Dhanbad. The institute has a campus of 218 acres located in Sardar Patel Nagar, Dhanbad. The Institute owns 11 hostel premises named after precious gems. The institute has a total og 6000+ students enrolled and 405 faculty members.
The Indian Institute of Technology Indore (IIT Indore), established in 2009, is a rapidly growing IIT located in Madhya Pradesh. Ranked 14th in Engineering (NIRF 2024), it offers cutting-edge programs and research across disciplines. The institute boasts strong placements and advanced research facilities.
The Indian Institute of Technology Gandhinagar (IITGN), established in 2008, is a student-focused technical university on a 400‑acre riverside campus in Gujarat. Ranked consistently in India’s top 20 engineering institutions. It has flexible interdisciplinary curricula with international exposure.
The Indian Institute of Technology Ropar (IIT Ropar) was established in 2008. It is situated on a 525-acre plot in Rupnagar, Punjab. Ranked 12th in IIRF 2025, it is home to approximately 3,000 residents. In the year 2024, 73% of B.Tech students were placed with an average package of ₹22.09 LPA
The Indian Institute of Technology Jodhpur was founded in 2008. IIT Jodhpur is a multidisciplinary institution fostering technology education and research. The institute is situated on an 852-acre campus outside Jodhpur and focuses on innovation, industry linkage, and has state-of-the-art laboratories and centres for state-of-the-art research.
The Indian Institute of Technology Mandi (IIT Mandi) was founded in 2009. The campus is spread across 538 acres in Mandi of Himachal Pradesh. Ranked at 31 among Engineering and 8 among Innovation by NIRF 2024. The overall package was ₹22.38 LPA, with the median at ₹18.5 LPA.
The Indian Institute of Technology Patna (IIT Patna), which opened in 2008, is located on a 501-acre plot in Bihta, Bihar, fully functional since 2015. IIT Patna received an average salary of ₹17 LPA, and top salaries went up to ₹45 LPA.
The Indian Institute of Technology Bhubaneswar (IIT Bhubaneswar)  was founded in 2008, is situated on a tranquil 936-acre campus at the base of Barunei Hill, Odisha. In 2024, IIT Bhubaneshwar received an average package of ₹17.16 LPA and a highest offer of ₹64 LPA.
Indian Institute of Technology Tirupati (IIT Tirupati) was set up in 2015. It is a third-generation IIT located on a 540-acre suburban campus in Andhra Pradesh. According to NIRF 2024, it stands at 61st in the field of engineering. IIT Tirupati focuses on research, with an 18-acre research park planned, and has the highest gender and faculty-to-student ratios among IITs
Indian Institute of Technology Jammu (IIT Jammu), established in 2016, functions from a permanent campus in the urban area covering 400 acres along Jagti, Jammu. It had a placement rate of 70.8% in 2024.
IIT Palakkad was founded in 2015. IIT Palakkad has a 500-acre campus in Kerala. It is ranked 64th in NIRF 2024, with 85–90% placement and an average package of ₹18 LPA and a ₹60 LPA top offer.
